sn22.89:4.1: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn22.89:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Phagguṇa was staying in the Jujube Tree Monastery, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.89:4.3: In the late afternoon those senior mendicants came out of solitude and addressed Venerable Dāsaka:
sn22.89:4.4: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka
sn22.89:4.7: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re alright. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading, not growing, is apparent.’”
sn22.89:4.8: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He went to Khemaka
sn22.89:4.11: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re alright. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn22.89:4.13: “Reverend, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
sn22.89:4.14: its growing, not fading, is apparent.”
sn22.89:5.1: Then Dāsaka went to those seniors and told them what had happened. They said:
sn22.89:5.6: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka
sn22.89:5.9: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:5.10: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:5.11: Do you regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self?’”
sn22.89:6.1: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:
sn22.89:6.8: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:6.9: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:6.11: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self.”
sn22.89:7.1: Then Dāsaka went to those seniors and told them what had happened. They said:
sn22.89:7.8: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka
sn22.89:7.11: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:7.12: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:7.14: If, as it seems, Venerable Khemaka, does not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self,
sn22.89:7.15: then he is a perfected one, with defilements ended.”
sn22.89:8.1: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:
sn22.89:8.7: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:8.8: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:8.10: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self, yet I am not a perfected one, with defilements ended.
sn22.89:8.11: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the construct ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.”
sn22.89:9.1: Then Dāsaka went to those seniors and told them what had happened. They said:
sn22.89:10.1: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka
sn22.89:10.4: when you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?
sn22.89:10.5: Is it form or apart from form? Is it feeling …
sn22.89:10.9: When you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?”
sn22.89:11.1: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:
sn22.89:11.11: “Enough, Reverend Dāsaka! What’s the point in running back and forth?
sn22.89:11.13: I’ll go to see the senior mendicants myself.”
sn22.89:12.1: Then Venerable Khemaka, leaning on a staff, went to those senior mendicants
sn22.89:12.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
sn22.89:12.5: “Reverend Khemaka, when you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?
sn22.89:12.6: Is it form or apart from form?
sn22.89:12.11: When you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?”
sn22.89:12.12: “Reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form,
sn22.89:12.14: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …
sn22.89:12.19: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the construct ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.
sn22.89:13.1: It’s like the scent of a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus.
sn22.89:13.2: Would it be right to say that
sn22.89:13.3: the scent belongs to the petals or the stalk or the pistil?”
sn22.89:13.5: “Then, reverends, how should it be said?”
sn22.89:13.6: “It would be right to say that the scent belongs to the flower.”
sn22.89:13.7: “In the same way, reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.
sn22.89:13.8: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …
sn22.89:13.12: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the construct ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.
sn22.89:14.1: Although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have
sn22.89:14.2: a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the tendency ‘I am’ which has not been uprooted.
sn22.89:14.3: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping masses.
sn22.89:14.4: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
sn22.89:14.8: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
sn22.89:14.9: As they do so, that lingering residue is uprooted.
sn22.89:15.1: Suppose there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled,
sn22.89:15.2: so the owners give it to a launderer.
sn22.89:15.3: The launderer kneads it thoroughly with salt, lye, and cow dung, and rinses it in clear water.
sn22.89:15.4: Although that cloth is clean and bright, it still has a lingering scent of salt, lye, or cow dung that had not dissipated.
sn22.89:15.5: The launderer returns it to its owners,
sn22.89:15.6: who store it in a chest permeated with scent.
sn22.89:15.7: And that lingering scent would dissipate.
sn22.89:15.8: In the same way, although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the tendency ‘I am’ which has not been uprooted.
sn22.89:15.9: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping masses.
sn22.89:15.10: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
sn22.89:15.14: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
sn22.89:15.15: As they do so, that lingering residue is uprooted.”
sn22.89:16.1: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Khemaka:
sn22.89:16.2: “We didn’t want to trouble Venerable Khemaka with our questions. But you’re capable of explaining, teaching, advocating, establishing, disclosing, analyzing, and clarifying the Buddha’s instructions in detail.
sn22.89:16.3: And that’s just what you’ve done.”
sn22.89:17.2: Uplifted, the senior mendicants approved of what Khemaka said.
sn22.89:17.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty senior mendicants and of Venerable Khemaka were freed from defilements without grasping.
